= Customize {product_rhdh_name}

Organizations want to modify the {product_rhdh_name} (RHDH) interface to align with their brand guidelines and polish the user experience. You can change {product_rhdh_name} appearance and theme elements to reflect organization, team, or project branding. 

This module explains how to change the title and logo of the {product_rhdh_name} theme and illustrates the method for customizing any of the available configuration options for RHDH deployments on OpenShift clusters.

{product_rhdh_name} provides two themes:

* The _{product_rhdh_name}_ theme features elements and colors integrated with the Red Hat look and feel seen in the OpenShift Web Console, ACM, Cockpit, and other familiar interfaces. It is the default.

* The _Backstage_ theme is the simple base theme from {product_rhdh_name}'s open source https://backstage.io/[Backstage^] core.

While more advanced project requirements might https://backstage.io/docs/conf/user-interface/#theming-architecture-overview[replace the entire theme^] with a custom provider or providers, this module focuses on the more common deployment task of modifying the included theme with visual elements that suit a company, brand, or team style.
// "this code will create a simple functional home page": 3570 lines of YAML
//
//  Some reluctance to include above link to backstage theme doc bc
// our theme engine is JS MUI, labeled LEGACY right up top above the fold

== Per-User Appearance Settings

Any {product_rhdh_name} user can select their preference from the provided *Light*, *Dark*, or *Auto* theme modes.

The default theme mode is Auto, which sets {product_rhdh_name}'s Light or Dark mode from the user's local system preferences.

=== Change the Theme Mode

To select a theme mode, click your user name at the top right of any Developer Hub view and select *Settings* from the displayed menu to open the settings screen. Select the desired mode from the _Appearance_ section.

image::customize-rhdh/uset-appearance.png[]

=== Save Screen Space

Each user can also choose whether to "pin" the left-hand sidebar in its expanded state, showing icons and names, or to collapse the sidebar to display only icons.

== Global Appearance Options

{product_rhdh_name} configuration is set in a file conventionally named `app-config.yaml`. To customize global elements of RHDH appearance, you'll modify settings in an app-config for your instance in the same way you would for any instance of RHDH or Backstage. Instead of a disk file, however, an OpenShift _ConfigMap_ will hold the `app-config.yaml` data for your RHDH instance.

=== What You Can Change

In the Developer Hub app-config, you can customize theme components including:

* Company name and logo
* Font color, size, and style of text in paragraphs, headings, headers, and buttons
* Header color and gradient

This module shows how to change the display title and logo to illustrate the procedure for customizing {product_rhdh_name} appearance. The setup-rhdh/foundations.html[Setup RHDH^] module uses the same method to configure functional aspects of a {product_rhdh_name} instance, like access control and plugin settings.
//check: intra-linking - is there a better notation? I'm just ~guessing the file ext .html and using any-ol external link notation

== Lab: Deploying {product_rhdh_name} with Custom Title and Logo

At the overview level, specifying a title and logo for your {product_rhdh_name} takes 3 primary steps:
First, you'll create a _Project_ (a namespace) for your custom RHDH instance. In that Project you'll create a _ConfigMap_ to store instance configuration, including an embedded image. Then, you'll create a short _CustomResource_ to define the RHDH instance you'd like the cluster to create and manage.

=== Create an OpenShift Project

. Go to the {openshift_console_url}[OpenShift Web Console^].
. Switch to the *Administrator* perspective using the *Perspective Switcher* in the top-left of the UI.
. Navigate to *Home > Projects*, then click the *Create project* button.
. Enter the name `brand-rhdh` in the displayed dialog, then click *Create*.
+
image::customize-rhdh/create-proj.png[]

=== The app-config ConfigMap

You'll customize the title and logo of an instance of {product_rhdh_name} by setting two keys in your app-config: `app.title` and `app.branding.fullLogo`.

==== `app.title`

The `app.title` key accepts a quoted string value to set the visible `<title>` element of pages in your {product_rhdh_name} instance. It's easiest to see this title in your browser window's title bar or in the label on a browser tab.

==== `app.branding.fullLogo`

The `fullLogo` key accepts a base64-encoded SVG, PNG, or JPEG image to be shown at the top left corner of {product_rhdh_name} pages.

image::customize-rhdh/fullLogo-default.png[]

{product_rhdh_name} uses encoded images for visual elements so they can be embedded in app-config rather than referencing an external file or URL.

This module provides an encoded image in the sample code for app-config. It also explains how to encode your own image.

==== Keys in the ConfigMap definition 

You can see `app.title` and `app.branding.fullLogo` in this excerpt from the ConfigMap YAML. The base64-encoded image is a very long text string, severely shortened here. The complete ConfigMap definition is in <<Appendix A>>, below.

[source,yaml]
----
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: rhdh-config
  namespace: brand-rhdh
data:
  app-config.yaml: |
    app:
      baseUrl: https://backstage-rhdh-brand-rhdh.{openshift_cluster_ingress_domain}
      title: "Project Ideal X - Developer Hub"
      branding:
        fullLogo: data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAIAAAACACAYAAADDPmHLAAAAAXNSRBAAIAAIdpAAQAAAABAAAAZgAAAAAAAABIAAAAAQAAAEgAAAABAAOg
        [...] # ABRIDGED. COPY COMPLETE CONFIGMAP AT PAGE BOTTOM.
        g9J9ogzh5qBGQAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==
[...]
----

===== Procedure: Create the ConfigMap

In the OpenShift Web Console, Administrator perspective, select *Workloads* to expand it, then select *ConfigMaps*.

Click the *Create ConfigMap* button at top right.
In the presented text entry field, delete the provided YAML skeleton entirely.

Copy the complete ConfigMap declaration from  _<<Appendix A>>_ at the bottom of this page. The explanation of the keys above is abridged for readability.

Paste the copied ConfigMap YAML into the empty text field, then click *Create* to commit your `brand-rhdh` ConfigMap.

===== Alternative: Create ConfigMap on the command line

[source,sh]
----
% cat > app-config.yaml
# Paste the ConfigMap YAML here
^D
% ls
app-config.yaml
% oc create configmap rhdh-config --from-file=app-config.yaml --namespace=brand-rhdh
----

===== How to make the encoded image (Optional)

You can produce an encoded image string in the format {product_rhdh_name} expects by doing something like the following on your local *nix system:

[source,sh]
----
% ls
logo.png # Your logo image
% PNGLOGOB64=$(base64 -i logo.png) # Var holds image in base64
% B64_FULL_LOGO="data:image/png;base64,$PNGLOGOB64" # Catenate type spec with encoded image
% echo $B64_FULL_LOGO # Echo result to terminal
data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAI8AAAA7CAYAAABCONnwAAAAAXNSR0IArs4c6QAAAAZiS0dEAP8A[...]
% echo $B64_FULL_LOGO > logo.b64 # Write result to file
----

Once you've catenated the image specification with the encoded image data, copy the result from your terminal, or _echo_(1) it out to a file and open the file in a program that makes copying easier. Use the string to replace the provided image data in your `rhdh-config` ConfigMap.

{product_rhdh_name} works best with source icon images in the scalable SVG format. It also supports PNG and JPEG icon images. This exercise uses a PNG source image for simplicity while retaining an alpha channel to look acceptable against the gray background.

If your source logo image is in the (more desirable) SVG format, specify `data:image/svg+xml;base64` in your B64_FULL_LOGO variable. For a jpeg, specify `data:image/jpeg;base64`.


=== Declare a Backstage Instance

You've stored a custom {product_rhdh_name} configuration in your `brand-rhdh` ConfigMap, where your instance will be able to find it. Now it's time to inform the {product_rhdh_name} Operator so it will deploy and maintain the set of RHDH components in your project on the OpenShift cluster. To do that, you'll create a `Backstage` Custom Resource -- a particular _kind_ of Resource defined in the cluster's API to represent an instance of {product_rhdh_name}. The key part of your Custom Resource is naming the _configMap_ that should be consulted for {product_rhdh_name} configuration. You can see your `rhdh-config` ConfigMap named in the `configMaps` list beneath application.appConfig:

[source,yaml,role=execute,subs=attributes+]
----
apiVersion: rhdh.redhat.com/v1alpha3
kind: Backstage
metadata:
  name: rhdh
  namespace: brand-rhdh
spec:
  application:
    appConfig:
      mountPath: /opt/app-root/src
      # This instructs the operator to mount the ConfigMap
      # that you created into the Backstage Pods
      configMaps:
        - name: rhdh-config
    route:
      enabled: true
  database:
    enableLocalDb: true
----

Copy this Custom Resource YAML to your computer's clipboard.

In the OpenShift Web Console, Administrator perspective, click the plus icon ("*+*") near the top right to expand its menu, then click *Import YAML*.

Paste the `Backstage` Custom Resource YAML from your clipboard into the presented text field. Click *Create* to apply the Resource on the cluster.

The {product_rhdh_name} Operator will respond by creating and managing the pods and components for an RHDH instance, according to the configuration it finds in your `brand-rhdh` ConfigMap.

It can take a few minutes for a new deployment to completely roll out.

=== Alternative: Create Backstage Instance on the Command Line

[source,sh]
----
% cat > brand-rhdh.yaml
# Paste CR YAML here
^D
% oc apply --filename=brand-rhdh.yaml --namespace=brand-rhdh
----

//== Advanced Settings
//
// TODO: Add advanced settings? (What's more advanced than base64'd svg?)
// Custom URLs
// The same technique can be employed to set a custom baseURL in your app-config ConfigMap,
// after arranging DNS and/or cluster resolution of the custom name to the Service

=== Visit your {product_rhdh_name} Instance

Access your {product_rhdh_name} deployment using the https://docs.redhat.com/en/documentation/openshift_container_platform/4.19/html-single/networking_overview/index#nw-understanding-networking-routes-ingress_understanding-networking[Route^] established by the RHDH Operator:

. Select *Networking > Routes* from the OpenShift Web Console's right-hand navigation.
. Check that your *brand-rhdh* project is selected in the project selector.
. Click the URL in the *Location* column on the *Routes* page. You should be presented with the {product_rhdh_name} sign-in dialog.
+
NOTE: If an *Application is not available* message is displayed when you click the Location, wait another 1-2 minutes. It can take some time for the pod readiness check to pass after a pod restart.
+
. Select *Guest* to log in with just enough privilege to see the results of your title and logo customizations.

image::customize-rhdh/brand-rhdh-logo.png[]



== Tech Docs

The TechDocs feature is installed by default with Red Hat Developer Hub. TechDocs provides a central and standardized system for creating, finding, and reading technical documentation.

* Docs-as-Code: Documentation source files are stored alongside code in the same repository, conventionally in Markdown format. This promotes a "docs-as-code" process, making it easier and more obvious for developers to update documentation with the codebase.

* Centralized, Yet Distributed: TechDocs centralizes the access point for all documentation within the Red Hat Developer Hub portal, while the documentation source files remain distributed across repositories owned by the teams that develop, use, and maintain them.

* Automated Rendering and Publishing: TechDocs generates static HTML from Markdown or similar source files. This integrates into CI/CD processes to automate publishing. The generated HTML files are collected, accessible, and, most importantly, searchable alongside code, repos, APIs and services in {product_rhdh_name}.

== Appendices

=== Appendix A

This is the complete ConfigMap definition including an embedded logo image. Used in ยง _<<Procedure: Create the ConfigMap>>_

[source,yaml,role=execute,subs=attributes+]
----
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: rhdh-config
  namespace: brand-rhdh
data:
  app-config.yaml: |
    app:
      baseUrl: https://backstage-rhdh-brand-rhdh.{openshift_cluster_ingress_domain}
      title: "Project Ideal X - Developer Hub"
      branding:
        fullLogo: data:image/png;base64,
    # Enable guest sign-in WITHOUT AUTHENTICATION.
    # This configuration is UNSAFE and suitable for TESTING ONLY.
    auth:
      providers:
        guest:
          dangerouslyAllowOutsideDevelopment: true
    backend:
      baseUrl: https://backstage-rhdh-brand-rhdh.{openshift_cluster_ingress_domain}
      cors:
        origin: https://backstage-rhdh-brand-rhdh.{openshift_cluster_ingress_domain}
----
